p: Chapter 4.1 verified alterations in short circuit frequency with adapted CTWD throughout the analysis of electrical properties. Referring to the state of the art, increasing CTWD leads to the formation of large volume droplets during material transfer in GMAW [ 25, 32]. Experimental investigations with a high velocity video recording confirmed a constant droplet growth with increasing CTWD. Figure 6 shows droplet formation in GMAW with differing CTWD of 12 mm, 28 mm and 44 mm at characteristic points during the short arc welding regime and correlated to the circled numbers in Figure 4b. The increase of CTWD is shown in uniform step size of 16 mm for equal welding parameters. Thereby, the formation of a new droplet on the electrode directly after short circuit phase is shown (compare Figure 4b, circle number 3) as well as droplet growth during arc time (compare Figure 4b, circle number 4). Furthermore, the maximum droplet size is displayed directly before the material transfer in the short circuit phase. The focus of the investigations was set to analyze droplet growth and size before material transition into the melt bead. Therefore, the short circuit phase with material transfer (compare Figure 4b, circle number 1) and arc re-ignition (compare Figure 4b, circle number 2) is not shown in Figure 6.
